generated_text: This work is a milestone in the study of hydrates, which are a class of minerals that are formed by the combination of water and gas under high pressure and temperature conditions. The hydrate formation is of great importance in the petroleum industry, as it is the main form of gas storage in the deep ocean and the continental margin. However, the structure of the hydrate is still a mystery, and the presence of guest molecules in the hydrate is a long-standing debate. In this work, we report the structure of a hydrate with guest molecules, which is a milestone in the study of hydrates.

We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators has a fully faithful embedding in the category of sets and functions. This provides a categorical foundation for the theory of Hilbert spaces, and resolves a long-standing question raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are the subject of intense research interest because of their unique life cycle and the potential for their use as model systems for the study of parasitism, evolution, and development. However, the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and the molecular basis for the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan is unknown. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite, and we show that myxozoans are a sister group to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results provide insights into the molecular basis of the extreme reduction in genome size and gene content that characterizes the Myxozoa. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of parasitism and the origin of multicellularity.

COVID-19 is a highly contagious disease that has caused a global pandemic. The disease is caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), which is able to evade the host innate immune response by blocking nuclear import of transcription factors, which are key players in the activation of the innate immune response. Our results unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which SARS-CoV-2 hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host innate immune response and could lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels.

Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. This instability in global grain trade will affect especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We quantify the magnitude of this instability and its consequences for the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries. Our results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The coexistence of species with different feeding preferences is a fundamental ecological process. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivores in semiarid African savanna. Our results suggest that species partition food resources, even when they are similar in size and digestive physiology. This suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammalian herbivore assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Moreover, businesses have widely differing beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many small businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is much less than expected, and that the majority of it is concentrated in convergence zones of the subtropical gyres. This distribution is mostly due to the size distribution of the debris, which is dominated by small particles. We suggest that the fate of the missing plastic debris is to be found in the ocean interior, where it may be responsible for a number of processes that are still to be discovered.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. We determined the age of 40 large presolar grains that were extracted from the Murchison meteorite. The grains have condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago, which is an important period in the history of the universe. We found that the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. Furthermore, we found that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium.

We show that the global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, with the motorized fleet increasing by a factor of 10. This has led to a significant increase in fishing effort, which has been accompanied by a decline in the effective catch per unit of effort. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. We also show that the global fleet is stabilizing, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This will challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Reproductive output is limited by the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy is limited by the amount of energy available to the mother, the amount of time she has to allocate to reproduction, and the amount of energy she can store for future reproduction. We show that the amount of energy available to the mother is increased by domestication and allomaternal care, and that this increase in energy is used to increase the size of the litter.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This suggests that VX-765 could be a promising drug for the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues. It is the primary regulator of blood flow, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is organized into specialized clusters of cells that are able to communicate with each other to coordinate these functions. This paper describes the nature of the communication network between these clusters and the properties of the network that are important for the endothelium to function as a whole. The findings are important for understanding the endothelium as a whole and for developing new therapies for cardiovascular diseases.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and accessible data is likely to remain high for some time. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data service that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We believe that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers, modelers, and policy makers, and hope that it will be a useful resource for the community.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. Inactivation is a fundamental property of potassium channels that allows them to be inactivated during periods of inactivity and to be activated during periods of activity. Inactivation is also involved in the regulation of the channel’s gating. We have identified a key residue that is involved in the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. This residue is crucial for the proper functioning of the channel and for the regulation of its gating.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates the host are not well understood. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate the microbiome. We find that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, some of which are antimicrobial. These results support the idea that anaerobic gut fungi are important producers of natural products that could be harnessed for therapeutic use.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

This work demonstrates the synthesis of multifunctional structures that can be used to design a wide range of mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors. The proposed approach can be used to design and manufacture structures with multiple material phases, which can be used to design and manufacture devices with specific and programmable behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 pathway, can mediate the reversal of the adult hemoglobin system toward a more fetal-like pattern. This is a major finding in the field of hemoglobin regulation, as it suggests that the hemoglobin system is not fixed but can be regulated by epigenetic mechanisms. This may have implications for the development of hemoglobinopathies and hemoglobin-based therapies.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of resistance to treatment is a major obstacle to successful treatment. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to treatment that is common in cancer, and we developed a strategy to overcome it.

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Our study shows that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through activation of the STIM/ORAI pathway. Our findings have implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. Instead, the policy failed to halt the decline of older forests, and the number of older-forest–associated birds continued to decline. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate was tested in vivo, and showed activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this work provide a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes and to other targets of interest.

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful for many image-processing problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. This study shows that exposure to electronic devices in the evening can have a negative impact on sleep. This is a major finding, as it shows that the light emitted by these devices can suppress melatonin, phase-delay the circadian clock, and reduce the quality of sleep. This is important because the use of electronic devices is increasing rapidly, and the negative impact on sleep may be a major contributor to the decline in sleep duration and quality.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the geologic record, but the cause of this cooling is still debated. One of the proposed causes is the impact of a bolide, and the abundance of magnetic grains and microspherules at the boundary supports this hypothesis. However, the origin of the magnetic grains and microspherules is still controversial. We show that the magnetic grains and microspherules are not of extraterrestrial origin, but are derived from the crust. Furthermore, the rare earth element and Sr and Nd isotope compositions of the magnetic grains and microspherules indicate that they are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America, suggesting that the magnetic grains and microspherules are of terrestrial origin and are a key to understanding the Younger Dryas cooling.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the periphery is not well understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the periphery, and that its expression in the adult is required for the suppression of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules and may be useful in the development of new therapeutics. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

We show that the size of the population does not enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of technology. This is a major finding in the field of cultural evolution, and it has important implications for the evolution of technology in human societies.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas APOE E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that the presence of APOE4 allele increases the accumulation of a complement component in the brain, suggesting that defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes may contribute to the increased vulnerability of APOE4 to AD. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth, and its formation mechanism is still unknown. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of iron, but the nucleation mechanism of the stable, hexagonal, close-packed (hcp) phase of iron, which is the main component of the inner core, has not been well understood. We show that the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hcp phase, and that the bcc phase is more stable than the hcp phase. This two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The present inner core is likely to be composed of bcc iron, which is a new finding.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers, who have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world can predict the neural responses of human observers to sentences with human-level accuracy. This suggests that predictive processing is a fundamental mechanism in the brain’s language system.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is still a black box. We show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that we are using the wrong black box. We introduce a new black box, which is stable, and show that it is possible to train it with a finite number of samples. This opens the door to a new era of scientific computing with deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in the 1972 classic experiment by the psychologist Daniel Kahneman and his colleagues. The experiment, which is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth, is itself a flawed experiment. It is discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research. In hindsight, this is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and is still with us today. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a rare reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are remarkably conserved, and that they are both capable of causing leprosy.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two pillars of quantum information science, which is the field of physics that studies quantum computers. The entanglement dynamics is a key ingredient in the study of quantum computers, and it is also a fundamental problem in quantum information science. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of the quasiparticles of the system. This result is a major breakthrough in the study of the entanglement dynamics, and it opens the door to the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which is a long-standing open problem.

The development of a safe and effective vaccine against COVID-19 is a top priority. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is highly attenuated, has a large-scale manufacturing potential, and is able to protect hamsters from the disease.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the historical spread of plague in Europe is poorly understood. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which was able to fit mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a wide range of data to understand the history of infectious diseases.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience for more than a century. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is still poorly understood. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of animals. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only associated with the evolution of brain size but also with the number of neurons in the brain.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This is an important finding that may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a key regulator of the dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell polarity establishment. ADF/cofilin is known to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of ADF/cofilin in severing and remodeling the actin cytoskeleton. They also suggest that ADF/cofilin may be a promising therapeutic target for a variety of diseases associated with actin filament networks, such as cancer metastasis and fibrosis.

Fructose, a type of sugar found in many fruits, is a major sweetener in many foods and beverages in the United States. This study suggests that fructose may be a stronger appetite suppressant than glucose, and that this effect may be mediated, at least in part, by differences in brain activation. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history and a unique genetic structure. We present a comprehensive analysis of the genetic diversity of the Malagasy people, which is the largest living group of hunter-gatherers in the world. We show that the Malagasy people have a unique genetic structure, which is the result of a combination of a recent settlement from Africa and a recent admixture from Southeast Asia.

We show that the content of people’s Facebook News Feeds influences their emotions. We also show that people are influenced by the emotions of others, and that this influence is not limited to in-person interactions. These results have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms.

The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not protein-coding, and the structure and function of noncoding RNAs are critical for cell survival. Chemical modifications of RNA are a key mechanism for regulating RNA structure and function, and the incorporation of modifications into messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a major focus of research. We show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can have a modest impact on translation. This work provides a foundation for understanding the impact of mRNA modifications on translation, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases associated with mRNA modifications.

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. It also has implications for the design of work and for the allocation of resources in society.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a fundamental aspect of the biology of these animals. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with the energetic demands of the aquatic medium, which are driving and confining aquatic mammals to larger body sizes. This work provides a quantitative framework for understanding the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals and may have implications for understanding the evolution of body size in other aquatic animals and for the design of aquatic habitats.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of rhinovirus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature is a key factor in the pathogenesis of the common cold. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for understanding the pathogenesis of the common cold and for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (Show more)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in humans and animals, and is one of the most difficult pathogens to eradicate from hospital environments. This is partly due to its ability to rapidly adapt to its environment, including the surfaces of medical devices, and to cause persistent infections. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of the surface, and that this sensing is used to regulate the expression of virulence factors and biofilm formation. This is an example of how bacteria can use their appendages for sensing and sensing systems for regulation of their behavior.

We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results are based on a comprehensive metaanalysis of 838 peer-reviewed studies (>2,500 sites in 73 countries) that evaluated the presence of pesticides in surface water. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results are based on a comprehensive metaanalysis of 838 peer-reviewed studies (>2,500 sites in 73 countries) that evaluated the presence of pesticides in surface water.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the virus continues to spread globally. Although the virus has been documented in many animal species, the role of animals in the transmission of the virus is not fully understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. This study highlights the need for a One Health approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world for decades. The proliferation of large dams in the Mekong River Basin, the Amazon River Basin, and the Congo River Basin is a case in point. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global public health crisis. The disease is characterized by chronic inflammation, which is most often attributed to the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and cell death. However, we show that soluble and oligomeric Aβ are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the earliest inflammatory response in AD. This finding has implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies, since targeting the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a more effective approach to the treatment of AD than conventional approaches. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary target for the prevention and treatment of AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Hellenistic period. This is supported by a survey of the Southern Levant, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of proteins at the single-molecule level. This method is based on the use of a short sequence of amino acids that is added to the protein at the beginning of the folding process. The sequence is then removed by chemical means, and the protein is allowed to fold. The extent of the chemical reaction is monitored by mass spectrometry, and the results are used to determine the structure of the protein at each stage of the folding process.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress, and their decapping activity has been shown to be critical for the function of the bacterial RNA caps. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is the predominant decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, is the primary enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress. Unexpectedly, RppH prefers to recognize capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. This shift in substrate specificity, coupled with the unconventional manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of RppH, could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Understanding the mechanisms by which these enzymes function could lead to the development of new strategies for controlling gene expression. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of the disease. In this study, we show that arginine, a major amino acid, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune system during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is a promising therapeutic agent to restore the immune system during sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This work also opens the door to the development of new therapeutic strategies for other diseases in which the immune system is involved. View Full-Text

We provide a global census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all mammals combined, and that the biomass of humans is comparable to that of all plants. We also show that the biomass of humans is comparable to that of all animals combined.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts and present a mathematical model of pattern formation and proportional growth. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronic and quantum applications. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture strain, which limits its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This opens up opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

This study provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of a unique class of peptides, the cysteine-rich peptides, and demonstrates the potential of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the contributions of the female reproductive tract to sperm are important for reproductive success. However, the extent of such contributions is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the viability of sperm during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular mechanisms underlying the male–female interface. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD and may be relevant to other diseases.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been a more challenging target, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the study of the impact of viruses on human health. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and we find that viruses are associated with many diseases. This resource will enable the study of the role of viruses in human health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is mainly due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL can measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously, which is not possible with current remote-sensing techniques. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate ACI. The results show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path but increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This is a significant contribution to the field of climate science. We expect that this technique will be widely used in the future.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of intense debate for more than a century. The temperature inferred from isotopic data is ∼15 °C today, but this value is subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic composition of the oceans, the potential for isotopic resetting, and the depositional environment. We present a method for determining the temperature of Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes, which are expected to have evolved under conditions of high temperature. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. This work highlights the importance of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data for understanding the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are also the targets of drugs. The pore gates of ion channels are the main sites of drug binding and are the targets of drug-induced conformational changes. The activation gate of K+ channels is the site of fast channel activation and is the target of drug-induced fast channel inactivation. The inactivation gate of K+ channels is the site of slow channel inactivation and is the target of drug-induced slow channel inactivation.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 1 million deaths occurring each year. The parasite uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, but the role of the red cell in the process is largely unknown. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the red cell, which in turn reduces a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding has major implications for our understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new antimalarial therapies.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronic and quantum applications. However, its properties are sensitive to defects, and it is difficult to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This opens up opportunities for tailoring its properties for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

This study provides evidence that low ambient humidity impairs host defense against influenza infection, and that this effect is mediated by the host response to influenza infection. This study also provides evidence that the host response to influenza infection is impaired by low humidity, and that this effect is mediated by the host response to influenza infection. This study provides evidence that the host response to influenza infection is impaired by low humidity, and that this effect is mediated by the host response to influenza infection.

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a left-corner parser, starting with the simplest elements and gradually adding more complex ones. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of syntactic structures is consistent with this hypothesis. We also show that the brain’s activity is not limited to the posterior superior temporal and inferior frontal cortices, but is distributed across multiple areas of the left hemisphere. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the brain’s language system.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is involved in many important processes in the body, including development and cancer. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin are not only similar at the protein level but also in their regulation. This is an important finding that may help to understand the function of redundant genes in the body.

This study provides a detailed description of the brain circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. It also provides a foundation for further studies of the role of this circuit in the etiology of obesity.

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is of fundamental importance to agriculture. However, the use of free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria as inoculants is limited by the lack of a sustainable way to control the establishment of the bacteria on the host plant. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be applied to other symbioses and could be used to develop sustainable nitrogen fixation in agriculture.

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the large number of unobserved factors that may have affected the outcomes. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Spiders are the most successful animal order, and the araneid spider is the most common and widespread spider. However, the spider’s ability to hear is not well understood. Here, we show that the spider’s web acts as an acoustic antenna, and that the spider can remotely sense the direction and location of sound by sensing the motion of the web. This provides a unique model for studying the sensing of sound-induced air particle movements, and for designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 vaccines are needed worldwide to contain the pandemic. We report the design, synthesis, and characterization of a recombinant protein that can be expressed in bacteria and presented on a virus-like particle to induce high-affinity neutralizing antibodies in mice. This protein variant is engineered to have high-yield manufacturability, high affinity for ACE2, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence used in current vaccines. This protein variant can be used to design a vaccine that can be manufactured at a large scale, and presented on a VLP to induce high-affinity neutralizing antibodies. This protein variant can also be used to design a vaccine that can be used to protect hamsters from SARS-CoV-2 infection.

We report on the identification of a ligand for the ALK/Ltk receptor tyrosine kinase family, which is involved in the development of the pigment cells of the zebrafish and Drosophila. This study provides a molecular basis for the involvement of ALK/Ltk receptors in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for multiple pandemics. The earliest genomes of Y. pestis are found in the Neolithic, and the timing of its emergence and the role of fleas in its transmission are still debated. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Y. pestis genomes from across Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during this critical period of development. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage of Y. pestis, which was replaced by a lineage adapted to the flea, and a rapid dispersal of the latter across Eurasia. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague. They also highlight the importance of studying ancient pathogens to understand the origins of diseases and their impact on human history.

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings also highlight the importance of gender-based political psychology to understand the gender gap in support for Trump and the election of other male candidates who espouse HM. The findings are also important for understanding the gender gap in support for Democratic and Republican candidates, as well as for understanding the gender gap in support for Democratic and Republican policies. The findings are also important for understanding the gender gap in support for Democratic and Republican policies.

The conversion of grasslands to agricultural production has been a major driver of the global C cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has released 1,000 to 2,000 Pg of C to the atmosphere, and this trend is expected to continue. We show that the management of grasslands and croplands can mitigate this trend and that the management of grasslands can be a key component of climate-smart agriculture.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a risk assessment framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinators to find the plant, but the color of the nectar of many plant species is unknown. We show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that the color of the red nectar of Jaltomata herrerae is similar to that of Nesocodon, suggesting convergent evolution of this trait. Our work provides evidence for the importance of the color of nectar as a cue for pollinators and suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new chemical class of alkaloids that may be of interest to the pharmaceutical industry.

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of women from the Early Medieval period in Europe. This is a period of great cultural change, and the genetic ancestry of these women is highly heterogeneous. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides insights into the processes that shaped the genetic landscape of Europe during this period.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of MERS-CoV and HKU4 and may help in the development of strategies to prevent and control future bat coronavirus cross-species transmissions. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using mNGS to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a resource-scarce setting. The study also highlights the importance of coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This study provides a blueprint for the use of mNGS in resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and inform public health response.

The human genome is replicated in a single-stranded template-directed manner, which is the opposite of the double-stranded template-directed replication that occurs in the nucleus. This replication of the lagging strand is performed by the pol δ holoenzyme, which is anchored to the PCNA sliding clamp. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a unique insight into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for the replication of the lagging strand. It also provides a unique model system for studying the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. This model system can be used to study the stability of other complexes that are anchored to the PCNA sliding clamp.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, RNA polymerase ribozymes can synthesize RNA molecules, but the activity of these enzymes is limited. Here, we report the results of an in vitro evolution experiment that led to the improvement of the activity and generality of an RNA polymerase ribozyme. The improved polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other time periods. We hope that our method will be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. We found that the patients with severe and critical COVID-19 have high levels of interleukin 6, which may be the cause of the inflammatory storm. Tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, may be a potential treatment for severe and critical COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to control copper toxicity is well established, but the identity of the fungal metabolites that bind copper and impact cellular copper content is unknown. We report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and the control of fungal interactions with competing microbes.

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, in a sedimentary rock at the surface of Mars is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous material is a diagenetic product of multiple aqueous fluid/solution events. The tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and amorphous silica are detrital, and the magnetite is detrital. The amorphous mixed-cation salts and oxides and possibly the magnetite are products of multiple aqueous fluid/solution events. The presence of tridymite, and the other minerals and amorphous material, in a sedimentary rock at the surface of Mars is a significant discovery.

Frost damage is a major threat to agriculture, forestry, and wildlife, but the geographic distribution of frost events and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants and animals are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that the resistance strategies of plants are not always well adapted to the new conditions. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of these cells are unknown. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may be important for the development of disease in inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and identify therapeutic targets. This will also enable high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that can alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This will be a major advance in ALS research and may lead to the development of new treatments for this devastating disease.

This study provides a unique example of a pathogen using a host protein to alter the gut microbiota of its vector, which in turn influences the pathogen’s ability to colonize the vector. This study also provides a model for how pathogens may use host proteins to influence the composition of the gut microbiota of their vector, which may be important for the pathogen’s ability to complete its life cycle.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds, as it is the key to understanding the origin of flight. However, the study of the evolution of the tail is complicated by the fact that the tail is a complex structure that is difficult to study in fossils. Here, we describe a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians, and show that this group of birds had a mosaic evolution, with the tail being modified in different ways in different lineages.

We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to the climate system, and that it is important to understand the role of the stratosphere in climate. We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to the climate system, and that it is important to understand the role of the stratosphere in climate.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism, and it is found in many species, including humans. In this study, we describe a mechanism that allows animals to change their color, and we show that this mechanism has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is enriched in cancer stem cells, and is associated with the maintenance of the cancer stem cell phenotype. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is the most widely read book in the world, and the first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we present a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction and recovery. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb zircon dates from five volcanic ash beds. The age model shows that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction, and the recovery was slow. These results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model also provides a precise time point for evaluating the timing of the recovery of the biota, which is critical for understanding the evolution of the modern biota. This work provides a critical link between the geological record and the biosphere.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the orphan nuclear receptor family, which is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is still unclear. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also find that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides insights into the function of RORα in the intestine and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for IBD. (Show more)

We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 in complex with the receptor ACE2. We find that the spike protein of the currently dominant variant of SARS-CoV-2, which contains the D614G mutation, is in a more open conformation than the spike protein of the original strain, which contains the D835G mutation. This finding suggests that the D614G mutation may increase the infectivity of the virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in 2020, the pandemic has resulted in a reduction in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003, and a reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y of 0.87 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the starting point for the development of chemical models and theories. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. Furthermore, we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. This work provides a chemical explanation for the pressure-induced metallization of the elements, and it opens the door to the development of a chemical theory of pressure-induced metallization.

We show that the effects of fire on climate are large and that the effects of fire on climate are not the same as the effects of climate on fire. We also show that the effects of fire on climate are not the same as the effects of fire on carbon. This is important for understanding the future of fire and its effects on climate, as well as for understanding the effects of fire on carbon.

This study provides a unique example of a symbiotic system in which the host provides a nutrient to its microbial partner, which is then metabolized by the host itself. This study also provides a model for understanding how the host may regulate the activities of the associated microbiota, and how this may be important for the health of the host.

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. This method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding, and it is applicable to many domains. We illustrate the method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method provides a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data. We hope that this method will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. View Full-Text

Asteroids are a group of marine invertebrates that are of economic and ecological importance. They are a food source for many species of fish and seabirds, and they are also a major component of the ecosystem. In the last 2 y, a disease has caused the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by starfish. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of starfish.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. We have identified IL1RAP (IL1R3) as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. IL1RAP is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. Finally, we generated an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Thus, our results provide a proof of principle for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach could be extended to other types of cancer.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history and a unique genetic structure. We present a comprehensive analysis of the genetic diversity of the Malagasy people, which is the largest living group of hunter-gatherers in the world. We show that the Malagasy people have a unique genetic structure, which is the result of a combination of a recent settlement from Africa and a recent admixture from Southeast Asia.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate gene expression. Some of these RNAs encode a small protein that has a function distinct from the RNA’s primary function. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of a glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress the expression of genes involved in galactose utilization. The protein and RNA compete for the same translation site, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has a function distinct from the RNA’s primary function.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules and may be useful in the development of new therapeutics. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of the agricultural community, and their knowledge is critical to monitor and manage agricultural production. However, the vast majority of agricultural countries do not have a system to collect and analyze this information. We show that the US Department of Agriculture Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is conducted by a large number of crop experts, can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of this type of system to provide continuous and accurate information on crop status, and highlight the importance of leveraging the knowledge of the agricultural community to improve agricultural management.

Language is a highly complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This is a new approach to memory that does not rely on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. It is also sensitive to the context in which information is stored, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is a key uncertainty in predicting future changes in atmospheric CO2 concentrations. In this study, we present the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration measurements, and we use this dataset to investigate the temperature response of soil respiration. Our analysis reveals that the temperature response of soil respiration is highly variable across biomes, and that the response is not consistent across all biomes, as has been suggested by some single-site studies. Our results suggest that the response of soil respiration to climate change may be regionally variable, with colder regions being more responsive to warming than warmer regions. This study provides a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is also one of the most dramatic changes in the history of the Earth, leading to the rise of the oxygenation of the atmosphere and the evolution of the first animals. The molecular mechanisms of this transition are still debated, and the molecular signature of the transition is poorly understood. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is linked to the loss of photosynthesis and the loss of genes involved in photosynthesis, and that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the loss of genes involved in the synthesis of the plastid envelope.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the most severe in the region in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of this event by a factor of five to six. This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also show that the drought risk in SSA will increase substantially under high-emission scenarios. This study provides a valuable contribution to the scientific community and to the public debate on the causes of the drought and its implications for the future. It also provides a useful example of how climate models can be used to quantify the impact of anthropogenic climate change on extreme events. This approach can be applied to other regions and events.
